Anyone who has heard of Crysis knows it is still heralded to this day as a benchmark for graphics. Based on the Cry Engine 2, even now it is absolutely stunning.   But more importantly its actually a brilliant game all round. The story is pretty standard, you are a special force operative kitted out with a 'Nano Suit' which allows you to perform as a super soldier, whilst on mission you discover an Alien species which are plotting to invade the world (or so it seems). Voice acting is pretty good, the facial mapping is OUTSTANDING!   But the key point that won this game for me was the true freedom it provides you in how you play. The map is very open, leaving it up to the player how you approach each objective. You can switch your suit to max armour and plow straight through the next check point murdering people left right and centre... you could turn on your optic camoflage and sneak through without a soul knowing, you could buff your strength, pick up an explosive barrel, hurl it at the building and watch the Crytek physics bring the roof down upon your foes. It really gives you the freedom to play it in a way that suits you and that is why I would recommend Crysis.

The game may be 9 years old, but the graphics can still compete with many new releases today. Sure there may be some assets that are not wuiet up to todays standards of games that are considered looking great today. For instance the palm trees may be a bit edgier than more modern trees that use tesselation. or some rock textures that aren't quiet as crisp as they could be. Everything else when it comes to graphics still holds up very well to new releases.  When it comes to performance the game should runs just fine on maximum graphics, as long as your system has decent hardware. im thinking soething like a gtx660 and some i5 should handle it just fine  Now that we got the 'graphics part' out of the way.  Let's get to the actual review: I played this game 9 years ago when it came out and I loved it. The Physics are some of the best I've seen in any game to date. You can destroy entire huts. Without having them collapse in a predetermined way. but instead theyll actually react physicly correct to how you interacted with them.  There are 10 Levels in the game. That are all pretty big. So there is no pre-determined way to go like in call of duty. Each of the levels are several square kilometers big that you can actually walk on. And there aren't really any areas that feel empty.  The AI is pretty smart for the most part. On the highest difficulty they are pretty hard to beat at times. However they aren't perfect ofcourse either. For instance in the 1st level there is a guy in a toilet. and 8/10 times when he gets alert to you he runs into the wall of the toilet instead of out through the door.  The Story is probably the games weakest feature, which doesn't say it's bad. It's just nothing particularly special either. That beeing said, as a little side note: The story in Crysis 2 is actually quiet an improvement over the one in Crysis 1.  And now the most important gameplay element: The nanosuit. For me this made it for one super cool, cause you are some super hero kind badass (with a slightly more grounded background lore to how the powers work than most comic book super heroes). And also I think it makes for some very fun options gameplay wise. You have great mobility with speed and strength mode. you can choose to fight as a tank with armor mode (although you still die very quick on delta difficulty so its not crazy overpowered) and you can play very stealthy with the cloak mode (which makes you almost but not completly invisible). All those abilities use the suit's energy, so they can not be used indefinitly. And the best thing is you can switch in between the diffrent suitmodes at any time, so you can adapt your playstyle to the situation at any given time.  Last: The Multiplayer: So appereantly the multiplayer doesn't work anymore due to the service it used (gamespy) shutting down. However there may be workarounds to still play online. And the LAN mode still works ofcourse. I personally didn't bother much with the multiplayer in crysis 1. Back when I tried it it seemed alright, but I don't think it lived auiet up to the potential of multiplayer fun there could have been with the nanosuit. crysis 2 was an improvement in that regard in my opinion.  So all in all Crysis 1(and I'm mainly referring to the singleplayer here) in my opinion is one of the best shooters ever made. And I'd recommend it to anyone who hasn't played it yet. (9/10) (10/10 if you choose to ignore the slightly weaker story)

For a long time, I had Crysis down as a graphics demonstration; all the looks & headlines but with no substance. Hardly surprising when all that was talked about was 'Can it Crysis?'.  However, I picked it up cheap in 2010 after building a fresh system & wanted to see what it could do.  It was only when I found I was riveted to the game did I realise that underneither the headline grabbing garphics, was a game that utterly appealled to me; it's a seriously immersive story that holds on to you for hour after hour.  The game play is excellent, switching suit modes is fast & intuitive, the gun upgrades are all worth considering & best of all you can be gung-ho if you want or you can stealth you way around & not really kill anyone & still acheive the mission objectives, the game simply sets you're objective, then lets you crack on with it, rather than forcing you one way or another, a trait that defines utterly iconic games like Deus-Ex.  The vehicles handle like boats though, much like Farcry, Crytek's first game & the climax is a little overblown. It's dramatic & exciting, right up until you fight the final 'boss'. However, like Bioshock, the build up is so enjoyable, any final battle is going to feel like an anticlimax.  Ultimately, the game ended with me chewing my hands for more, which means that it's succeeded in engrossing me in the world it's creating, which is the one thing I demand. An excellent multiplayer is all well & good, but if a game has a story line, in my mind, it has to stand on that alone or not at all. Crysis doesn't need the graphics or EA's massive marketing department to be a truly noteable game, but it does help make us aware of it.

Crysis has had a strange life since it's release in 2007. At the time of it's release it was by far the most technologically challenging game to play, utilizing graphics that would make even the high end PC's of the time scream in terror. Because of this simple fact it was for the longest time mentioned in conversation much as one would mention a benchmark tool and throughout gaming, that is how it was viewed. A measure of the strength of your PC. A strange fate for a game.  Although there has never been much concern for the game beneath the graphics Crysis isn't a bad game. Although it does nothing new or revolutionary it is a good solid FPS that is spared the horrors of knee high walls that often afflicts other games in this genre.  You play as a super soldier wearing the Crytek version of power armor, a skintight bodysuit that lets you active various temporary abilities such as invisibility and bullet absorption. Although the attempt at stealth is fairly half-hearted the ability to leap 20 feet into the air and jump 60 miles per hour allows you to engage enemies in a variety of ways and that certainly helps keep the gunplay fresh.  The storyline is fairly standard, supersoldier stuff and the voice-acting doesn't go completely bad despite some poorly casted movie stars as your supporting cast.  All in all it's a fun play although not a game I think would have ever been made much noise about if it wasn't for the incredible graphics.

I have to go out on a limb here and say that this is actually one of the best FPS games I ever played, period.  Others may point out the deficiencies, but through the curious way I experienced this game it has ultimately assumed the status of an absolute classic in my eyes.  That experience I mention is this: On my first ever playthrough, my rig was such that the game crashed as soon as I entered the final act - all that water and all those explosions, you dig? - and so I never actually knew that it was the final act. In my mind the game stretched on into inifinity - and what an infinity it was.   The game goes through three distinct phases, each more jaw-droppingly perfect than the last. At first, one is navigating a jungly-coated tropical island world, evading - or annihilating, though this was never as fun for me - conventional, dastardly Korean forces in a manner strongly remeniscent of the original Far Cry (for me at least, Far Cry didn't really have any stealth component, though i did everything i could to force it to play like a stealth shooter nonetheless) In the second phase, all-out conflict has broken out and, while you can continue to play as a phantom if you wish, the stakes and scale soar upwards into 'epic' territory. In the third phase, you discover a vast and fantastic secret lurking within the island, exploring this secret in a state of permawonder, before re-emerging into a drastically altered form of the second phase, to see out the game.  My initial experience was cut short most of the way through the third phase, so in my mind it was, as I've said, neverending, and by jebus that neverending game was FPS fantasy made reality. It really is just an awesome game.  Quite apart form the graphics, which are to this day superior to almost any other offering of comprable setting (visually if not technolgically, though the tech is still close), the gameplay is tight and perfectly polished. This is the kind of game that, while vaguely linear, allows a player to turn 100m of linear progression into around 1km of side-track meandering and sneaking more or less throughout the entire experience. One can craft one's own adventure here, as surely as any of those gimmicky kids books from the '90s, and just as everyone had envisioned in their wildest dreams back then this adventure is lush, endless and full of wonders more wonderous than the last.  The gameplay is consistent and with the possible exception of the final moments of the second phase, in which combat is more or less forced on you and the game literally ejects any background action in an effort - only marginally succesful - to turn your final stage into some kind of arena, it is consistently entertaining.  Why should you buy this game? Because your computer may very well finally be able to run it in something approaching max settings, because it is one of the best FPS experiences you will ever play, and because it is streets, miles ahead of any other  similar  game released in the years before or the years after.

I remember when this was considered a trial by fire for anyone's computer, even today some low end rigs struggle to run it.  It's a nice game, perhaps set back by it's stiffy for post-processing, but there's a functional experience here at least, it annoyed me that the multiplayer didn't have vehicles, that was introduced in Crysis Warhead.  Aaaaanyway, Crysis begins when your squad is sent to the Lingshan islands to rescue a research team who have uncovered something big, and dangerous. Ancient technology of an alien civilization buried in the earth.  And now I'm sitting in the same pose as that History Channel bloke, ALIENS.  Outside of combatting an awakening alien scourge, you fight against a division of the Korean Military who have occupied the island due to the discovery, using stealth, wits, various vehicles, and your Nanosuit to overcome the challenges facing you.  The game also features a realtime weapon modification mechanic, allowing you to swap out attachments and ammo types on the fly, you unlock these attachments as you find them ingame, my personal recommendation is to use an assault scope and a silencer on your FY-71, and then keep a Precision Rifle with a Sniper scope handy for those crucial shots.  I will not spoil any of the game's major plot points, play it for yourself if you are interested.

Basically, the game starts out as a poor-man's Far Cry, and winds up being a poor-man's Halo.   The production value here for 2007 is quite impressive, and holds up extremely well.   Don't let the Gamespy installation tempt you. Since it's dead, of course there is no multiplayer, and therefore no reason to install that bit. Just skip it when it prompts you.   The game unfortunately is riddled with bugs, and a couple in particular are game-stopping. If you can get past this, the core game itself is pretty good. The multitudinous foliage of the jungle does factor into stealth (unlike many games with similar concepts/settings), but since you're wearing a badass nanosuit you do have the option of run-and-gun.   I will say however that being able to turn invisible, even for short lengths of time, is an unfair playground for anyone even remotely good at stealth gameplay. In fact, if you ARE good at stealth gameplay, being invisible for short periods threaten to crush the game's difficulty, if you are so inclined. Inexplicably, in spite of so many excellent stealth elements there are absoutely no stealth kills in the game. You don't even have a knife. What kind of spec-ops soldier doesn't have a knife? Plenty of suppressors you can attach for weapons, but you'll have to wait until Crysis 2 to actually shank someone from behind.  The game does a good job of APPEARING to be open-world, but it actually isn't. It's still on rails, those are just some very wide rails.   The AI was good, surprisingly. No real complaints, and that's pretty rare for me.   One minor complaint is that in spite of being a badass (thanks to you), the main character is fairly dim-witted. It doesn't help that many things are left unexplained not only in this game, but the sequel as well. All-in-all, the game is an epic ride if you can ignore the many flaws.

To preface: I am not an avid fan of the FPS genre. I can enjoy games when they are well made, but the mechanics of FPS games do not inherently have much appeal to me.  Its really hard to say much about this game. I'm sure it was an amazing title when it came out but it doesn't age well because the story is thin and not fleshed out. As such it ends up as just another shooter, maybe a little less boring than the others.   Performance in this game suffers hard. On my 6850 HD / 2.8ghz *6 / 12GB system on a mix of High/Med visuals the game NEVER got above 35FPS if any action or foliage was on screen. In the end part of the game impossible slowdown would occur, causing frame dips into the single digits. Even reducing resolution and graphics options did not remedy this, although some persistence and restarting the game several times helped make it through. The game did not throw event triggers properly at least four or five times in my playthrough, requiring reloading of earlier saves. Physics interactions were also problematic, making slowdown from colliding objects and leading to vehicles becoming inescapably stuck. The graphics quality does seem alright, but since none of the environments have any artistic influence or design aside from the alien area its mostly wasted.  Gameplay does not stray far from the formula, but that is to be expected of AAA games. Its more or less the same formula as Far Cry down to the letter, with the addition of a stamina meter that also serves as regenerating shield and cloak. Everything is the same. Stealth isn't meaningful, the open environments are still actually linear, enemies spot you from a bit farther away than is reasonable (better than far cry at least) and have horrible pathing and AI. Gun variety is par for the course and more or less feels fine. Vehicles are still overpowered for their mounted guns, and enemies with mounted guns are still problematic. Environments are all generic jungle up until the end of the game. The characters are all stereotypes and completely lack depth.   The game's story is intentionally incomplete, doesn't cohere well, and cuts short at the end in a sequel hook so painful it almost feels insulting. You have a few moments that don't really mesh. Enemy nano-suit wearers ambush you once but never appear again. You have to perform a pseudo escort mission for an ally presumed dead after escaping some aliens and then he just bails for the sequel hook. The koreans just exist as convenient foreigners for you to shoot at until the aliens appear. I don't think its strange to want story in an FPS or any other game, but its a different kind of appeal I guess between Deus Ex or Bioshock Infinite or Fallout NV and something more arcadey like this. Far Cry 1 dragged on forever with its pacing over 15 hours and this game just suddenly ends with no resolution after 10 hours.   There's... nothing special about this game. Its just solid enough to not be terrible and looks alright. You're better off spending your money elsewhere, certainly not worth the $20 being asked for today. No reason to not wait for a sale if you're going to bother at all.

Crysis is the best and worst of gaming.  The best is it's got all this emergent gameplay based around simulation, where there is a giant map you can seemingly go anywhere in, can accomplish objectives however you want. Blow up all the buildings, drive all of the vehicles.  Your suit has a great mechanic to it where you can select between 'modes' like strength, speed, or armor, and run around  The game is surprisingly low budget as well, but uses every dollar spent to maximum effectiveness, because it's not about the 'guided cinematic experience' but rather the actual gameplay.  The bad is the gameplay isn't all that great.   All of the randomness in the gameplay systems makes for a frustrating experience. Mostly this takes the place of weapon accuracy where you are forver at the mercy of RNGesus. Sometimes you can waltz into the middle of a crowd of enemies and one shot them all to the face. Sometimes you can shoot into a wall and the enemies still die. Other times RNGeus will dictate your shotgun blasts all miss and the AI gets headshots at the same time and you die instantly. Sometimes enemies take 3 seconds to react to you standing directy in front of them. Other times you get insantly killed by a mounted machine gun on a boat 1 km away while you are hiding in the bushes.   Other games with recoil, even in 2007, usually make it feel good by making the camera shake so the weapon always shoots where it points, in a semi-random pattern you can learn to control. In this game the bullets spray out in a random pattern around the reticle, in addition to randomly rotating your camera to simulate unsteady aim, in addition to randomly rotating your reticle because of screen space 'cinematic' effects.  The audio sounds good sometimes, and bad other times. There is an issue with prioritizing effects here. Stuff like distant explosions has no audio at all, because the game doesn't know that is more important than a nearby ambient sound.  Something with the rendering pipeline seems to be adding significant display lag to things. This is often done when people want to really push graphics, as you can parallelize things better if you can delay processing of graphics stages by several frames so the CPU isn't spent waiting. Unfortunately in this case it seems to mean where you shoot isn't where the graphics is rendering you will shoot, but rather where you are in the simulated world. This is just too much lag for a FPS game that asks for precision. RNGesus may be here to try and mask this issue.  The end result is the gameplay loop is reduced to this: save often.   This may have been the norm in 2007, but playing it in 2016... yeah it's not worth finishing IMO.

Pros: - Excellent graphics. Seriously, almost a decade old, and it holds up very well.  - The macho military dialog is groan-worthy, but it's fun. 'You want guarantees? Get a toaster!' - Some really cool level designs. It's generally very clear which direction you need to move in; there are a lot of visual cues that help guide you through some of the busier environments. There were quite a few instances where I found that I knew where to go without really *knowing* that I knew it, and that's always a good sign. - A variety of ways to move through the level, especially in the early going. A recent review called it more of a 'wide corridor' than a true open-world, but it feels open enough.  Cons: - Gunplay isn't bad, but I never felt like weapons were varied enough - or had enough ammo - to really make me like one over any other. I tended to just grab whatever was lying around. - Some overly long missions without much variety. I can only be entertained by moving into a new room and killing the three identical enemies contained therein for so long. - And the big one - it feels needlessly frustrating in some places. Dark Souls is frustrating but feels fair, for the most part. Crysis is frustrating and feels capricious. There's a tank level partway through, and I figured, hey, this'll be sweet. But it's not. You get one tank for the first half, a second tank for the second half. Every enemy has RPGs. Something kept falling from the sky and killing me. Enemy tanks hit hard. You can't repair your tank. If you lose your tank, that's it - you have a huge field to slog through, and you better hope you don't run up against an enemy vehicle, because you're screwed if you do. It should feel cool; it should make you feel powerful. But it doesn't.   The other big moment like this is at the end of the game. I won't spoil anything, but let me advise you to look around your environment and find the box of infinite rockets that the game, helpfully, does not tell you about, or the minigun which is wisely hidden amidst flaming wreckage. Can't just hand out that kind of power.   If it weren't for the atrocious design of the final level, I would still recommend Crysis. But in my opinion, it's too frustrating, and diminishes the entire experience.

Derided by many as more of a techdemo than an actual game on release, Crysis actually revolutionised tactical first person shooters by virtue of two very smart (and intertwined) design choices: One, by setting the game on a large, semi open-world island, thus allowing the player to tackle seemingly simple 'go to position X' missions in a variety of ways; and two -- and it is here that the game sets itself apart from Crytek's previous outing Far Cry --, by giving the player access to a variety of superpowers (speed, strength, invisibility, armor), as well as the ability to quickly change between these powers on the fly. In other words, the player is free to advance from checkpoint to checkpoint in his own way, both literally (as in choosing his path) and metaphorically (as in choosing his playstyle). And crucially, while a one-to-one combat situation is bound to be boring in a game that outfits the player with numerous superpowers, the enemies still hit hard and find strength in superior numbers, so as to not make the game a cakewalk.  Yet the plot of Crysis, unimaginative from the start but seemingly an afterthought anyway, eventually comes to influence the mechanics of the game and does so for the worse: Aliens briefly appear early in the game, then vanish again for several hours before becoming the principal antagonists of the second half of the game. Thus, the intricate setpieces of the first half -- the infiltration of a shipyard a definite high point --, usually culminating in intense firefights against Korean soldiers, give way to monotonous battles against lazily designed aliens. Instead of infiltrating a base, the player suddenly finds himself following a very straight and narrow path for 20 minutes, steadily interrupted by groups of three identical enemies and packs of conveniently placed ammo, since the aliens do not drop any.  4/5

Far Cry is released, made by the same developers i thought i'd give crysis a run, hearing reviews from people saying its fantastic, 97% rated among others, So i thought i'd run Crysis. Even though the game is a 2008 creation it is visually stunning on my 2012 rig.   The year is 2020, You invade a small island in the South China Sea, after US archeologists uncover a mysterious artifact and The North Korean government quickly seizes the area, imprisoning the archeolgists. You start off as a member of Delta Force sent in on a rescue mission and one by one your team is eliminated by some sort of alien force.   Crysis is a next-generation PC first-person shooter from Crytek, the award-winning developers of 'Far Cry.'   During the siege the true nature of the artifact quickly emerges, pointing to the existence of an alien presence on Earth, and ultimately the trigger for a massive-scale alien invasion.   The battle to save Earth begins...   Despite the realistic near-future setting and familiar arms, Crysis isn't a military simulation. At its heart this is a superhero game, where the main character is armed with the latest in high-tech equipment. Your nanosuit -- the star of the show -- allows you to be invisible, to be super-fast, to be super-strong, or to be virtually bulletproof. Here's the catch: you can only use one power at a time, and they all have limited energy. Choosing which powers to use in every situation is the heart of the gameplay.  For the most part the powers are excellently balanced. Each has its drawbacks and situations where it's appropriate to use (any power, improperly used, will drain your suit's energy and shut off). The only exception is super strength, which isn't terribly useful in most scenarios.   Stealth, on the other hand, is absolutely essential. You are always outnumbered. Fortunately, stealth is brilliantly implemented: While standing still, your suit can stay invisible almost indefinitely. But the moment you start moving, your energy drops... fast. The gameplay that results is absolutely pulse-pounding. You'll dart from cover to cover, stealing moments wherever possible to recharge your suit. While standing still, enemies will walk right past you, unaware you're pointing a shotgun at their head.  Apart from the occasional crashes and then almost at the end of the game it failing to run at all even in compatibility mode then i would still recommend the game.

Crytek must practice witchcraft in their spare time, because creating visuals of this calibre, and in as early as 2007, is a simply ludicrous feat. And to top it all off, the game itself isn't half bad either.  The story for Crysis begins on a small Pacific Island. Set in the year 2020, players take the role of Nomad, who is sent in to rescue a group of archeologists and investigate some strange signals being transmitted from the island. Upon arriving you soon discover that an alien invasion is upon the planet, and you quickly become embroiled in fighting for not only your survival but fighting to stop the invasion.   Crysis backs up it's great story line with excellent and intuitive game play. You are equiped with a powerful suit, an exoskeleton called the Nanosuit. This nanosuit grants you enhanced strength, super speed and the ability to cloak. The suit is the defining aspect of the game play, with the suit's feature's enabling a far deeper level of choice and greater number of options in every situation you encounter. Crysis seams to transcend genres, with stealth, rush and precision tactics all viable if needed. The weapons in Crysis are all brilliant, modernised but not so much so that they feel tacky, and expertly equipped with brilliant sound effects. The visuals and environments in Crysis are simply fabulous, but the open nature and freedom of these large environments is what makes Crysis such a joy to play. If you have a powerful enough CPU and Graphics Card then you're in store for some truly mind blowing graphics. Foliage casts shafts of light to the ground, water ripples in real time around you and other objects. Crytek didn't leave a stone unturned in detailing both the environments and character models. The texturing and lighting effects are amazing, especially when cranked up to highest settings, some aspects yet to be topped by even it's sequels.  About the only flaw I could detect from Crysis is that the game eventually ends, an issue that in reality is unavoidable. For this reason, I cannot legitimately mark down Crysis, but what I can deduct is the game's length instead. This game does quite a few things right. I think what I enjoy most, however, is the way it handles secondary objectives. In most other games, secondary objectives are either too hidden, or made too explicit. The former gives me an endless gut feeling that I've missed out on something the game has to offer. The latter makes them feel less 'secondary'. Crysis just throws a green and a yellow blip on the map, letting you know 'Hey this exists' without ever making you feel like missing it is really going to screw you over. Lump that philosophy in with the games quasi-sandbox nature, and we have a winner. Granted, the side objectives could afford to have a bit more incentive, but the framework is there, and it's nice. Overall, the game is slightly above average. It remains relevant as a milestone in graphics, but its shooting mechanics are middling. Despite that, it's still fairly easy to have fun, and that's kind of the point.

I remember the times of old when Crysis was used to benchmark everything. It's a game I fondly remember for it's brillant and fun gameplay with gorgeous visuals that put modern games to shame but it's far from perfect.  Graphically, it was easily the most taxing game when it came out. 'Can it run Crysis on max?' was a common way to judge a computer's performance, and rightly so, it's a intense game to run. Although released in 2007, it still looks gorgeous. The Lingshan Islands feel like very realistic in it's scope and detail. Texture quality rivals, if not outright better than, modern textures, and lighting effects are done to perfect. All in all, it's visually stunning. Worthy to note is the interactivity of objects in the game. The ability to shoot at enemies in cover and destroy their cover completely is realistic and not to mention being able to break most objects in game. Houses, fences, trees and cars are all destructable and this should be abused to the best of your abilities.  Gameplay wise, it's a sandbox, first person shooter, and arguably the best of it's genre. Guns feel like they have a real kick to them and the shotgun especially feels immensely satifisying to use compared to modern first person shooters. The nanosuit has 4 but all very distinct and useful 'modes'. All 4 modes use energy, an automatically recharging resource, to power their actions. Power mode allows for steadier aim, stronger melee attacks and higher jumps[/spoiler]. Armor modes allows damage to be absorbed via energy. Speed mode allows for faster movement in every situation including walking, crouched walking, running and even moving up ladders (not to mention a ridiculously fast sprint). Finally Cloak mode allows for limited invisibility. However, being tied to a limit and ever draining resource, there is an art to using the functions of the nanosuit. It's immensely satisfying to cloak into cover behind an enemy, switch to power mode, headshot, and then use speed mode to quickly sprint away into new cover. There's also a bit of depth into the mechanincs of the nanosuit, and the game doesn't hold your hand into it. It never tells you to use power mode when you're trying to snipe at long distances, or to use speed mode sprinting while swimming or   in zero-g environments   to move rapidly. Guns feature on-the-fly customisation, and you can tailor each gun to each specific circumstance, such as adding a silencer with a sniper scope on your assault rifle to act as a long range sniper, or switch it up with a reflex scope and grenade launcher for drawn out firefights. There are a few vehicles to use including tanks, military jeeps and even VTOLs but they're nothing really special apart from using jeeps in creative ways to kill KPA soldiers in the first half of the game.  Storywise, it's very barebones. You're sent to investigate an island who have american researchers taken hostage by the North Korean military (KPA or Korean People's Army). It then is revealed   that an alien race is lying dormant with the KPA trying to use them as an limitless energy source. This backfires and instead wakes the aliens and the US military arrives to try and stop them before they contact their homeworld for reinforcements.     The few main characters are lively and full of character, especially your squadmates of Raptor Team. Their voice actors do a terrific job putting so much personality into them, including the voice actors for quite a lot of the characters you'll meet. Although there is an exception. Helena Rosenthal was done by Claudia Black, responsible for Chloe in the Uncharted Series and Morrigan in the DA series. She does an okay job in those, but she is absolutely awful in Crysis. Whenever Helena's voice comes on it's like a nails on a chalk board. Absolutely jarring and breaks your immersion. You really have to think how the production team okayed this, when the other characters like Psycho or Prophet are done so well.  However the game is ultimately flawed in many aspects that take away from the experience. The first half of the game is a brillant open world FPS that allows for creative ways to approach every objective. Abusing Cloak feels cheap, but mastery is difficult to achieve resulting in a rather balanced experience. You can still end up in a terrible position with no energy to absorb hits if you don't position properly which means instant death at the higher difficulties. Enemies can also spot you while cloaked if you move in close proximity to them and even while remaining still if they're in touching range. Personally, I play this like a Predator simulator, and it's immensely satifisying to cloak in and out, while headshotting soldiers undetected and causing an alert to go off while you continute to flank and pick soliders off one by one. Unfortunately once you reach the second half of the game, it becomes a completely different game. After you reach   the mines and the alien temple within  , it becomes a linear FPS with bullet sponge enemies (The aliens you'll fight, the KPA nanosuit soliders aren't so bad). While this isn't bad on it's own, you have to play a completely different style. You can't stealth kill (as in cloaking and headshotting) and so you are forced to shoot behind cover, ducking to recover your armor. I wouldn't mind this in it's own game, but to lose that sense of freedom and ability to play as you see fit from the first half, is a real shame. The game also suffers from numerous bugs, including odd physics interactions like a fallen tree shaking and walking into it causing instant death, falling into the floor of the   USS Constitution and getting stuck   and the infamous bug where you crash upon trying to load a game (which you can fix by deleting the most recent save in your savegame folder).  All in all, it's an immensely fun game to play with multiple ways to play it as you see fit. The visuals are gorgeous and constant screenshot worthy moments. Although there are a few bugs (some almost game breaking), the overall experience is worth to chug through them. I would advise to replay the first half after finishing the game though, you'll see just how much more fun it was if you didn't notice it already.

I've been itching to be the badass in the suit for some time, and as our protagonist is an uber-macho ultra-masculine Iron Man, it can be quite entertaining to tromp around in his NanoBoots. However I was disappointed by some of the glaring technical issues which have been left unattended by CryTek since its arrival on Steam.  You wear the NanoSuit in the first iteration of the photorealistic experience, becoming the ultimate soldier. Prepare to Maximum your way through enemy forces, alien strongholds and countless gorgeously rendered trees and foliage.  Crysis was for nearly a decade the gold standard for performance: 'Sure the server's fast, but will it run Crysis?' Modern systems can still be tasked by the demanding CryEngine in its earliest release. Unfortunately it has not aged well, and graphical flaws can break the visual flow, such as spawning objects incorrectly and even breaking mission targets.  Electronic Arts and Crytek issued their final patches in 2007, and it has not received any attention since, which casts a shadow on its asking price. Do not pay full price for this game. Instead, buy it as part a bundle or in a sale. It is a satisfying experience for the hardcore, and even casual shooter.  Stone dumb AI amuses more often than frustrate, and once you learn their recognition patterns, you're nearly untouchable. All that said, this is a fun futuristic if somewhat thoughtfless romp.

Still looks amazing, still fun. Slighty dated mechanics. Possible technical issues. But, fun is what matters.  -- Technical: AMD FX-8350 nVidia GTX 970 Windows 10 Pro 64 Game would black screen on start, but it wasn't hard to find a patch that allows it to run on 64 bit. -- Review: This game came out in 2007, and it feels like it. The graphics are still amazing, and look better than some of the games now, but the overall mechanics feel dated.  The story so far is a bit generic. Aliens. The enemy AI is laughable. They have no problem finding loud noises or seeing you. They're even blind if you're standing in tall grass, which is something games now can learn from. Where the AI really fails is finding you when you're using a silencer. If you shoot a wall, they will predictably, look toward where you fired. But, if you get them with a body shot, they will still frantically look around trying to find you. I hit you in the body!! How do you not know where I’m shooting from!?! Likewise, if you kill an enemy next to another, that enemy will have trouble finding you as well. This makes the silencer rather overpowered, and takes the difficulty down to a minimum. The game tries to emphasize stealth, alerting the enemies to your presence will usually result in many more enemies herding to your location. Unfortunately, stealth kills weren’t a standard mechanic at the time. You can however pick up your enemy and use them like a shield, though they die fairly quickly. The cloaking ability itself is rather overpowered as well. You can easily switch back and forth between cloak and armor, using a small amount of cover to regenerate your energy.  Where the game shines most is in the minor features that games now really should have. Highly destructible environments. You can throw a grenade into a building, and the thing will collapse down, killing anyone inside. You can also chop down a tree with your gun, then proceed to chop that tree into several pieces. Weapon customization is done during the missions, and by picking up other weapons, you can add their mods to your repertoire. This allows you to change your style according to the situation that you’re about to enter. The overall style of this game is great, with amazing art. Very good immersion. And… It’s just fun. The level designs allow you to approach an area however you want and play in your own style. The weapon customizations allow you to tweak based on your current situation. The gameplay is just fun.
